unittitle.value: American Guild of Variety Artists Records

p.value: Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Donated by Jerry Dunbar, counsel to the American Guild of Variety Artists, in 1982. The accession number associated with this gift is 1982.002.
"A History of the American Guild of Variety Artists: Dissertation Proposal," by Lori Seward, NYU Department of Performance Studies. Eventually, Ms. Seward chose another topic for her dissertation.

The records of the American Guild of Variety Artists have been grouped into series by function and format, and where possible, arranged in rough chronological order. The collection has not been processed or refoldered. The files, in their disorder, redundancy, and gaps, reflect the sometimes chaotic administration of the union. The collection documents not only AGVA's history, including its internal struggles, but also its role in post-World War II popular culture. Historians will also find insights into the content of members' performances, their working conditions, business relations in the industry, and long-term trends in entertainment from the impact of mass media on live entertainment, to the brief vogues of "amateur hours" and go-go dancers. <emph render="bold">NOTE: This collection is housed offsite and advance notice is required for use.</emph>

corpname.value: Associated Actors and Artistes of America

Series I: MinutesScope and Content Note

Series I: Minutes, 1948-1979, 22 linear feet. Includes minutes of the National Board, 1948-1968; National Executive Committee, 1948-1969, 1979; New York Branch, Membership and Executive Committee, 1958-1974 (with gaps); Branch minutes from Providence, St. Louis, Toronto, San Francisco, Sarasota-Tampa, 1947-57 (sporadic). Minutes include actions taken, communications, election results, reports on branches and trial boards and other materials. In general, they are not comprehensive with many gaps and overlaps.

Series IV: Correspondence, 1948-1975, 35 linear feet. Includes correspondence of officers Jackie Bright, National Administrative Secretary; Jack Irving, Executive Secretary; Russell Swann, secretary Treasurer; Penny Singleton, Executive President, on all aspects of union administration: jurisdictional disputes, organizing drives, negotiations and contract administration, branches. Also included are four linear feet of correspondence from the Chicago branch, including branch minutes, between 1962 and 1974.

Series V: Membership, 1949-1974, 10 linear feet. Includes a selected sample of correspondence from members. Although much of it is routine, the correspondence sometimes sheds light on the content of members' performances, working conditions and long-term trends in the industry. Of particular interest are the photos and resumes submitted during the years AGVA sponsored its Auditions (1958-60).

American Guild of Variety Artists (AGVA)

Scope and Content Note

The American Guild of Variety Artists (AGVA) is an AFL-CIO-affiliated labor union founded in 1939 to represent performing artists and stage managers for live performances in the variety field. The variety area of performance includes singers and dancers in touring shows and in theatrical revues, theme park performers, skaters, circus performers, comedians & stand-up comics, cabaret & club artists, lecturers, poets, monologists, spokespersons, and variety performers working at private parties special events. AGVA is a branch of The Associated Actors and Artistes of America. AGVA negotiates contracts and provides relief for members. The website contains information on their relief funds, auditions, news, and other information.

Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements

Due to technical or privacy issues, archived websites may not be exact copies of the original website at the time of the web crawl. Certain file types will not be captured dependent on how they are embedded in the site. Other parts of websites that the crawler has difficulty capturing includes Javascript, streaming content, database-driven content, and highly interactive content. Full-Text searches of archived websites are available at https://archive-it.org/organizations/567.
